figureOfSpeech: Comment ca se plume(lit.: How is it plucking?)
translation: How are you? How are things?

figureOfSpeech: Ca porte les memes calecons.(lit.: They wear the same underpants.)
translation: They are always together.

figureOfSpeech: Quand les poules auront des dents(lit.: When chickens have teeth
translation: Never.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir des fesses de moiselle(lit.: To have mosquitohawk buttocks)
translation: To have a thin buttocks, a skinny behind.

figureOfSpeech: Deteler le wagon au milieu du marais(lit.: to unharness the wagon in the middle of the swamp)
translation: To give up in the middle of an undertaking.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir les narines effleurees.(lit.: To have flaring nostrils)
translation: To be angry

figureOfSpeech: Capotez pas la maison!(lit.: Don't turn the house over!
translation: Calm down!; quiet down!

figureOfSpeech: Les boulangeries se sont battues.(lit.: The bakeries had a fight.)
translation: There is frost on the ground.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir la langue trop longue.(lit.: Tongue is too long.
translation: To talk too much.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir tous leur tetes dans le meme bonnet.(lit.: To have all their heads in the same bonnet.)
translation: Of several people to think alike; to be in complete agreement.

figureOfSpeech: Comment le cabri apporte sa queue?(lit.:how is the goat carrying his tail?)
translation: How are you? How are things?

figureOfSpeech: Casser sa vaiselle.(lit.: To break one's dishes.)
translation: 1. To break up(of a couple or household). 2. To fall down and hurt oneself.

figureOfSpeech: Ca c'etait quand Fido etait petit.(lit.: That was when Fido was small.)
translation: That was a long time ago.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir des jambes comme des pattes de moqueur.(lit.: To have mockingbird legs.)
translation: To have thin legs.

figureOfSpeech: A la va vite.(lit.: To go quickly style.)
translation: Quickly and not very well.

figureOfSpeech: Attraper une touche.(lit.: To catch a touch.)
translation: To get tired out, worn out.

figureOfSpeech: Baton de vieillesse.(lit.: Old age stick.)
translation: A person who can be depended on for help in one's old age.

figureOfSpeech: Balai du ciel.(lit.: Broom of the sky.)
translation: A northwest wind.

figureOfSpeech: Arretez votre tactac.(lit.: Stop your popcorn.)
translation: Stop all the talking!

figureOfSpeech: Ca coupe comme une jambe de chien.(lit.: That cuts like a dog's leg.)
translation: It doesn't cut; it is not very sharp.

figureOfSpeech: Comment ca se brasse?(lit.: How are things stirring up?)
translation: How are you? How are things going?

figureOfSpeech: C'est comme le feu et l'eau(lit.: They're like fire and water
translation: They're always quarreling/fighting.

figureOfSpeech: Il doit etre apres manger du patasa.(lit.: He must be eating sunfish.)
translation: He's taking a long time.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir des oreilles comme un taxi avec les deux portes ouvertes.(lit.: To have ears like a taxi with both doors open.)
translation: To have big ears.

figureOfSpeech: Vider la mer avec un baril defonce.(lit.: To empty the sea with a broken barrel.)
translation: To do a task which requires great effort but accomplishes nothing.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir la cache.(lit.: To have the hiding place.)
translation: To be in great fear.

figureOfSpeech: Enfant de deuxieme lit.(lit.: Child of a second bed.)
translation: Child of a second marriage.

figureOfSpeech: Mouiller jusqu'a les chiens buvaient debout.(lit.: To rain until dogs drank standing up.)
translation: To rain very much.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir un bon coup de fourchette.(lit.: To have a good fork technique.)
translation: To be a big eater, a glutton.

figureOfSpeech: Une grenouille de benitier.(lit.: A baptismal font frog.)
translation: A woman who volunteers often at church.

figureOfSpeech: Mieux que ca et les pretres seraient jaloux.(lit.: Any better than this, and the priests would be jealous.)
translation: Things are going very well.

figureOfSpeech: Comme des patates et des puces.(lit.: Like potatoes and fleas.
translation: People or things which go together naturally.

figureOfSpeech: Au diable bouilli.(lit.: To the boiled devil.)
translation: In a distant and unknown place.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir un crapaud dans la gorge(lit.: To have a toad in the throat)
translation: To be hoarse.

figureOfSpeech: Tourner en eau de boudin.(lit.: To turn into boudin water.)
translation: To become insignificant.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir les yeux egares.(lit.: To have wild eyes.)
translation: To be lost or disoriented.

figureOfSpeech: Un petit tonnerre.(lit.: A little thunder.)
translation: A highly active child.

figureOfSpeech: Les pierres sont apres bruler.(lit.: The rocks are burning.)
translation: There is a mist or vapor rising from the ground.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir le diable dans le corps.(lit.: To have the devil in one's body.)
translation: To be mischievous, hyperactive.

figureOfSpeech: Un reve de poulet.(A chicken's dream.)
translation: An unrealistic idea or plan.

figureOfSpeech: Quoi ca dit?(lit.: What do you say?)
translation: What's up? What's new? What's happening?

figureOfSpeech: Faire chaudiere ensemble.(lit.: To make a cooking pot together.)
translation: To get married.

figureOfSpeech: Le chien qui va a la chasse perd sa place.(lit.: The dog who goes hunting loses its place.)
translation: If you leave your place, someone will usurp/take it.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir un nez comme un bec.(lit.: To have a nose like a beak.)
translation: To have a long, pointed nose.

figureOfSpeech: Pondre un oeuf.(lit.: To lay an egg.)
translation: 1. To mess up. 2. To say something unbelievable.

figureOfSpeech: Avoir un tour de lune.(lit.: To have a moon spell.)
translation: To be in a contrary mood.

figureOfSpeech: Jeu de chien tourne en bataille.(lit.: Dog's game becomes a fight.)
translation: Horseplay can lead to an argument.

figureOfSpeech: Un vent a decorner un boeuf.(lit.: A wind to dehorn a bull.)
translation: A very strong wind.

figureOfSpeech: Etouffeur de canards morts.(lit.: A strangler of dead ducks.)
translation: Someone who overdoes things, exaggerates his actions.

figureOfSpeech: Se coller un temps.(lit.: To stick oneself a time.)
translation: To have a good time.

figureOfSpeech: C'est l'heure qu'on leve la patte(lit.: It's time to raise a foot
translation: It's time to go.

figureOfSpeech: Sauter la manche a balai.(lit.: To jump the broomstick.)
translation: To live together without being married.

figureOfSpeech: Tous les tremblements de terre.(lit.: Every earthquake.)
translation: Every once in a while; infrequently.

figureOfSpeech: Ses cheveux sont tous chien-fou.(lit.: his/her hair are all dog crazy.)
translation: His/her hair are disheveled.

figureOfSpeech: Laisser(quelqu'un) en plan.
translation: To abandon(a friend).

figureOfSpeech: Fache comme un chien enrage.(lit.: As angry as a rabid dog.)
translation: Very very angry.

figureOfSpeech: A peche de la bande.(lit.: The peach of the group.)
translation: 1. The prettiest daughter of the family. 2. The prettiest girl of the group.

figureOfSpeech: Vents de Careme.(lit.: Lenten winds)
translation: Spring/March winds.

figureOfSpeech: Defonceur de portes ouvertes.(lit.: One who breaks down open doors.)
translation: A rough, brutish person; one who uses excess force.

figureOfSpeech: Tamiser la vie.(lit.: To sift life.)
translation: To get the most out of life; to live life to its fullest.

figureOfSpeech: On a plein d'huile dans la lampe(lit.: We still have plenty of oil in the lamp.)
translation: You don't have to go yet; it's still early.

figureOfSpeech: Se casser le cou.(lit.: To break one's neck.)
translation: To get married.

figureOfSpeech: On peut pas y mettre une epingle.(lit.: You can't fit a pin in there.)
translation: There is no more room; the space in question is very crowded.

figureOfSpeech: Il faut qu'il se tourne pour faire un ombrage.(lit.: He has to turn(sideways) to make a shadow.)
translation: He is very thin.

figureOfSpeech: Lacher la patate.(lit.: To drop the potato.)
translation: 1. To give up. 2. To mess up.

figureOfSpeech: Faire son boudin.(lit.: To make one's boudin.)
translation: To pout.

figureOfSpeech: Un petit rien tout neuf.(lit.: A brand new little nothing.
translation: A nonsensical response used to avoid answering questions.

figureOfSpeech: Maison de crapaud.(lit.: Toad house.)
translation: Mushroom;toadstool.

figureOfSpeech: En patate.(lit.: In potatoes.)
translation: In excess; in great quantity.

figureOfSpeech: le sirop et biscuits cassent pas egal.(lit.: The syrup and the biscuits don't even out.)
translation: Vengeance never evens out/rights a wrong.

figureOfSpeech: Mieux que ca serait un enterrement(lit.: Any better than this would be a funeral.)
translation: Things are going very well.

figureOfSpeech: C'est le faim et la soif.(lit.: It's hunger and thirst.)
translation: One is as bad as the other.

figureOfSpeech: La piste est seche.(lit.: The path is dry.)
translation: No one is there. The place is empty.

figureOfSpeech: Membre comme une tortue de rosee.(lit.: Built like a dew turtle.)
translation: Husky; muscular.

figureOfSpeech: Goudronner.(lit.: To tar up.)
translation: To mess up.

figureOfSpeech: Mettre de l'eau dans son vin.(lit.: To put water in one's wine.)
translation: To calm down; to temper one's remarks, particularly when angry.

figureOfSpeech: La fleur de lis.(lit.: Iris)
translation: The seventh daughter of a family.

figureOfSpeech: Chandelle de glace.(lit.: Ice candle.)
translation: Icicle.

figureOfSpeech: Gagner le sucre.(lit.: To win sugar/candy.)
translation: To show oneself as outstanding or superior; to win the prize.

figureOfSpeech: La roue tourne.(lit.: The wheel turns.)
translation: Things change.

figureOfSpeech: Quand on parle de la bete, on voit sa tete(lit.: When you talk about the beast, you see its head)
translation: Speak of the devil.

figureOfSpeech: Donner son capot(a quelqu'un)(lit.: To give(someone) his jacket/coat).
translation: To reject or break up with a suitor.

figureOfSpeech: Les finfifonds.(lit.: In the deepest, farthest place.)
translation: In a very remote place; the boondocks.

figureOfSpeech: En ceinture.(lit.: Belted.)
translation: Pregnant.

figureOfSpeech: Lacher la baratte.(lit.: To drop the churn.)
translation: To give up.

figureOfSpeech: Faire un gombo de babines.(lit.: To make a gumbo of lower lips.)
translation: To sulk, usually with others; to have a pity party.

figureOfSpeech: Petit gateau.(lit.: Little cake/cookie)
translation: Favorite child.

figureOfSpeech: Temps boucane.(lit.: Smoky weather.)
translation: Gloomy, overcast weather.

figureOfSpeech: Pese bouton, paie couillon.(lit.: Push button, pay fool.)
translation: Fancy gadgets are not worth the money one pays for them.

figureOfSpeech: Ca creve les yeux.(lit.: That hurts one's eyes.)
translation: That's obvious.

figureOfSpeech: Est-ce que t'amenes la pluie?(Are you bringing rain with you?
translation: Long time, no see.

figureOfSpeech: Etre a dos.(lit.: To be back to back.)
translation: To be on bad terms in a relationship.

figureOfSpeech: Au large(lit.: Out to sea)
translation: 1. Out on the prairie. 2. Far away.

figureOfSpeech: Crapaud(de nez).(lit.: Nose toad,)
translation: A booger.

figureOfSpeech: Faire une coche mal taillee.(lit.: To make a badly carved notch.)
translation: To make a big mistake.

figureOfSpeech: Frais/fraiche comme un lapin.(As fresh as a rabbit.)
translation: Invigorated; ready to go; fiesty; energetic.

figureOfSpeech: Un tonnerre a la voile.(lit.: A thunderbolt in the sail.)
translation: A noisy, unruly person, typically a child.

figureOfSpeech: Mouiller jusqu'a les vaches beuglent.(lit.: To rain to the point where the cows moo.)
translation: To rain a lot.

figureOfSpeech: Etre a rang d'oignons.(lit.: To be in rows of onions.)
translation: To be assembled in a large crowd.

figureOfSpeech: Ca coupe la langue de ma grand-mere.(lit.: That cuts like my grandmother's tongue.)
translation: It is very sharp(literally and figuratively.
